case_name: Income-tax Officer, Central Circle XIV, Calcutta v. M/s Mugneeram Bangur & Co., Land Department, Calcutta

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 310 of 1964 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 13, 1961 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 74 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 310 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 13, 1961 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 74 of 1956. D. Karkhanis, Gopal Singh and R.N. Sachthey, for the appellant.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer, Central Circle XIV, Calcutta, filed an appeal before the Tribunal against the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income Tax, Range-A, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of this case the Income-tax Officer, Central Circle XIV, Calcutta, was companypetent to file the appeal before the Tribunal against the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income Tax, Range-A. Calcutta?

facts.text: The respondent, M/s Mugneeram Bangur & Co., Land Department, Calcutta, were a firm carrying on the business of land development in Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts and circumstances are these. The respondent, M s Mugneeram Bangur Co.  Land Department  Calcutta  hereinafter referred to as the vendors  were a firm carrying on the business of land development in Calcutta.

facts.text: By an agreement dated July 7, 1948, the partners of the firm agreed to sell all the business of the said firm to the Amalgamated Development Limited, promoted by the partners of the firm.

anchor.surface_text: By an agreement dated July 7, 1948, the partners of the firm agreed to sell all the business of the said firm to the Amalgamated Development Limited, here in after called the vendee, which companypany was promoted by the partners of the firm.

facts.text: The vendors agreed to sell and the company agreed to purchase all the said business with effect from the eighth day of July One thousand nine hundred and forty-eight.

anchor.surface_text: The Vendors do hereby agree to sell and the companypany both hereby agree to purchase All That the said business with effect from the eighth day of July One thousand nine hundred and forty-eight.

facts.text: The sale included the goodwill of the said business and all stock in trade, fixtures, tools, implements, furniture, fittings and all other articles belonging to the said business.

anchor.surface_text: Together with the goodwill of the said business And all stock in trade, fixtures. tools, implements. furniture, fittings and all other articles and things belonging to the said business or in any way used in the same including the benefit and advantages of all companytracts.

facts.text: The purchase price was Rupees thirty-four lakhs ninety-nine thousand and three hundred, paid by allotting 17,500 Redeemable Preference shares of Rs. 100 each and 17,493 Ordinary shares of Rs. 100 each.

anchor.surface_text: The purchase price shall be Rupees thirty-four lakhs ninty-nine thousand and three hundred paid and satisfied by the Company allotting to the Vendors or their numberinees seventeen thousand five hundred Redeemable Preference shares of Rupees one hundred each and seventeen thousand four hundred and ninetythree Ordinary s hares of Rupees one hundred each in the capital of the Company which will be accepted by the Vendors in full satisfaction of the said purchase price.

facts.text: The company undertook to discharge all debts and liabilities of the vendors except liabilities for Income-tax, Super-tax or any other tax on income or revenue in respect of the profits of the business.

anchor.surface_text: The Company shall undertake and discharge all debts and liabilities of the Vendors including development expenses such as opening out roads, laying out drains and sanitary arrangements providing electricity in the areas and providing a School in Tolly gunge for education of Children for which the Vendors have given an undertaking to the Tollygunge Municipality and also the liability of the Vendors in respect of the deposits made with them by various intending purchasers of lands but excluding the liabilities of the Vendors for Income-tax, Super-tax or any other tax or duty on income or revenue in respect of the profits of the business.

facts.text: The schedule showed Land at Rs. 12,68,628 7 7, Goodwill Rs. 2,50,000, total assets Rs. 36,21,029 less liabilities Rs. 1,21,729 equaling Rs. 34,99,300.

anchor.surface_text: The sum of Rs. 34,99,300 was arrived at in the Schedule thus  In rupees  Laud 12,68,628 7 7 Goodwill . 2,50,000 0 0 Motor Car Lorries 25,866 8 6 Furniture, Fixture etc 5,244 5 6 Mortgage secured 71,62,367 6 0 Deposits for purchase of land 53,500 0 0 Advance paid to pleaders solicitors, companytractors staff and other outstanding 1,83,622 3 6 Cash in Bank 71,800 1 8 ---------------- 36,21,029 0 9 Less liabilities 1,21,729 0 9 ------------------ 34,99,300 0 0

facts.text: The Income Tax Officer held that the sum of Rs. 2,50,000 was actually charged by the vendors as a lump sum amount of profits on sale of valuable stock in trade.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer held that the sum of Rs. 2,50,000 was actually charged by the vendors as a lump sum amount of profits on sale of valuable stock in trade and number goodwill as alleged.

facts.text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that Rs. 2,50,000 was the value of goodwill and since transfer of business as going concern, profit was capital gain not liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner, on appeal, held that the said sum of Rs. 2,50,000 was the value of the goodwill. He further held that since the transfer was a transfer of business as a going companycern, the profit was the capital gain and therefore number liable to tax.

facts.text: The Appellate Tribunal held that the sale was of a business as a going concern but value of stock could be traced, so profits on sale taxable; Rs. 2,50,000 excess value of lands.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal held that although the sale was the sale of a business as a going companycern, the value of the stock companyld be traced, and, therefore, the profits arising out of the sale was taxable income.

facts.text: Tribunal dismissed the appeal holding transaction mere adjustment of business position of partners, Income Tax Department not entitled to take book-keeping entries as evidence of profit.

anchor.surface_text: But the Tribunal dismissed the appeal on the ground that although the vendors were a different entity from the vendee, the first being a partnership and the second being a limited companypany, the transaction was mere adjustment of the business position of the partners.

facts.text: High Court answered question 4: no profit in the transaction by which entire stock in trade and business transferred to limited company.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court first answered question No. 4, thus There was numberprofit in the transaction by which the entire stock in trade and the business of the firm were transferred to the limited companypany.

facts.text: High Court held for question 2: Rs. 2,50,000 shown as goodwill represented surplus on sale of lands, stock-in-trade.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding question No. 2, the High Court held that as the assets of the firm transferred to the companypany have been itemised and as there can be numberquestion of variation of the figures given in items 3 to 8 in the agreement for sale, it must be held that Rs. 2,50,000 shown as the value of the goodwill must be represented by surplus on the sale of lands which was the stock-in-trade of the assessee companypany.

facts.text: The entire share capital of the vendee company excepting seven ordinary shares was taken over by the vendor firm in lieu of the sale price.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of this case and in view of the findings of the Tribunal that the entire share capital of the vendee companypany  excepting seven ordinary shares  was taken over by the vendor firm in lieu of the sale price of the business as a whole, there was any profit in the amount of Rs. 2,50,000

facts.text: Two outsiders were brought in as directors with seven shares allotted to them out of 39,300 shares.

anchor.surface_text: Again the fact that two outsiders were brought in as directors with seven shares allotted to them out of 39,300 shares makes numberdifference.

facts.text: The vendors business involved buying land, developing it (roads, drains, electricity, school) and selling it.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the vendors were engaged in buying land, developing it and then selling it. The agreement itself shows that the vendors had already incurred debts and liabilities for development expenses such as opening out roads, laying out drains and, sanitary arrangements, providing electricity and providing for a school.

facts.text: Supreme Court held the sale was of the whole concern as going concern, no part of slump price attributable to stock-in-trade (land).

anchor.surface_text: In our view the sale was the sale of the whole companycern and numberpart of the slump price is attributable to the companyt of land. If this is so, it is clear from the decision of this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Kerala v. 14lest Coast Chemicals and Industries Ltd. 1  and Doughtys case 2  that numberpart of the slump price is taxable. We, therefore, answer question No. 3 in the negative.

facts.text: Question No. 1 was given up before the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention that it is number necessary to deal with question No. 1 because it was given up before the High Court.

facts.text: Mugneeram Bangur Co. Land Department was a separate firm consisting of the same partners as Mugneeram Bangur Co. with different shares.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that there was much value of the goodwill of the business that was transferred. Mugneeram Bangur Co. was a firm companystituting of several partners and Mugneeram Bangur Co. Land Department was a separate firm companysisting of the same partners with. however. different shares in the firm

facts.text: Conveyances of lands and buildings were executed in the name of Mugneeram Bangur Co.

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was drawn by the Department Representative to the fact that in the case of transfer of lands and buildings of the assessee firm the companyveyances were as a rule executed in the name of Mugneeram Bangur Co. The assessees learned Counsel did number object to this fact.

facts.text: The consideration of Rs. 34,99,300 was paid by allotment of shares to vendors-partners or nominees.

anchor.surface_text: The companysideration of Rs. 34,99,300 was paid by allotment of 17,500 Redeemable Preference shares of Rs. 100 each and 17,493 Ordinary shares of Rs. 100 each, the allotment being to the vendors-partners or their numberinees.

facts.text: Vendors had given undertaking to Tollygunge Municipality for school.

anchor.surface_text: providing a School in Tolly gunge for education of Children for which the Vendors have given an undertaking to the Tollygunge Municipality

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal findings accepted that entire share capital except seven shares taken by vendor firm.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of this case and in view of the findings of the Tribunal that the entire share capital of the vendee companypany  excepting seven ordinary shares  was taken over by the vendor firm in lieu of the sale price of the business as a whole, there was any profit in the amount of Rs. 2,50,000 the same being taxable under the Indian Income Tax Act?
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 13, 1961 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 74 of 1956.

The relevant facts and circumstances are these.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal held that although the sale was the sale of a business as a going concern, the value of the stock could be traced, and, therefore, the profits arising out of the sale was taxable income.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Rs. 2,50,000 attributed to goodwill is added to the companyt of land, it is numberodys case that this represented the market value of the land. In our

arguments.court_reasoning: No portion of slump price attributable to stock-in-trade as no evidence of separate valuation

arguments.claim: There was not much value of the goodwill of the business that was transferred; Rs. 2,50,000 was really the excess value of the lands sold along with the other assets.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that there was much value of the goodwill of the business that was transferred. Mugneeram Bangur Co. was a firm consisting of several partners and Mugneeram Bangur Co. Land Department was a separate firm consisting of the same partners with. however. different shares in the firm

arguments.claim: The transaction was mere adjustment of the business position of the partners; Income Tax Department not entitled to take mere book-keeping entries as the evidence of any profit.

anchor.surface_text: But the Tribunal dismissed the appeal on the ground that although the vendors were a different entity from the vendee, the first being a partnership and the second being a limited company, the transaction was mere adjustment of the business position of the partners.

arguments.claim: There was no profit in the transaction by which the entire stock in trade and the business of the firm were transferred to the limited company.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court first answered question No. 4, thus There was no profit in the transaction by which the entire stock in trade and the business of the firm were transferred to the limited company. Again the fact that two outsiders were brought in as directors with seven shares allotted to them out of 39,300 shares makes no difference.

arguments.claim: Rs. 2,50,000 shown as the value of the goodwill must be represented by surplus on the sale of lands which was the stock-in-trade of the assessee company.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding question No. 2, the High Court held that as the assets of the firm transferred to the company have been itemised and as there can be no question of variation of the figures given in items 3 to 8 in the agreement for sale, it must be held that Rs. 2,50,000 shown as the value of the goodwill must be represented by surplus on the sale of lands which was the stock-in-trade of the assessee company.

arguments.claim: Even if the value of the stock in trade taken over by the assessee was greater than the figure shown therefore in the agreement for sale in view of the answer to question 4, there was no profit which could be taxed.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding question No. 3, the High Court held that even if the value of the stock in trade taken over by the assessee was greater than the figure shown therefore in the agreement for sale in view of the answer to question 4, there was no profit which could be taxed.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Rs. 2,50,000 attributed to goodwill is added to the companyt of land, it is numberodys case that this represented the market value of the land. In our

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed no taxable profit from slump sale of going concern

arguments.claim: Doughty's case was wrongly decided in one respect; vendors and vendee different entities, not permissible to tear corporate veil; thus real sale and profits arose.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Karkhanis, learned counsel for the appellant, urges that the Doughtys case 1 was wrongly decided in one respect and that the vendors and the vendee being different entities. it is not permissible to tear the corporate veil to see whether the partners of the vendors were the same persons as the shareholders of the vendee.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to tear veil as sale treated on its terms as going concern slump sale

arguments.claim: If the third question is answered in favour, it would not be necessary to deal with the other questions.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: sale of the stock. and numbervaluation of the stock as an item forming part of the aggregate which w

arguments.court_reasoning: Court agreed and focused on Q3

arguments.claim: The sale was a sale of business as a going concern; Doughty's case applies.

anchor.surface_text: As we are inclined to answer the third question in the favour of the vendors, it is not necessary to deal with the other questions and the arguments addressed in respect of them. The Appellate Tribunal held in this case that the sale was a sale of business as a going concern.

arguments.claim: Facts similar to Doughty's case: slump transaction, no separate sale or valuation of stock.

anchor.surface_text: This is also apparent from clause 1 of the agreement set out above. If this is so Doughtys case 1 applies. The facts in Doughtys case may be conveniently taken from the headnote in that case.

arguments.claim: Income-tax is tax on income; sale of whole concern at profit not taxable unless traceable item.

anchor.surface_text: In connection with this ground, Lord Phillimore observed that income-tax being a tax upon income, it is well established that the sale of a whole concern which can be shown to be a sale at a profit as compared with the price given for the business, or at which it stands in the books does not give rise to as profit taxable to income-tax.

arguments.claim: Where slump price paid and no portion attributable to stock-in-trade, no taxable profit (citing West Coast Chemicals understanding of Doughty).
Vendors not purely buying and selling land but developing it; easy to distinguish realisation from ordinary sale; difficult to attribute slump price to land.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the vendors were engaged in buying land, developing it and then selling it. The agreement itself shows that the vendors had already incurred debts and liabilities for development expenses such as opening out roads, laying out drains and, sanitary arrangements, providing electricity and providing for a school.

arguments.claim: Schedule shows book cost of land, not market value; no evidence of valuation on sale date; adding goodwill not prove market value.
Sale was of whole concern and no part of slump price attributable to cost of land; no part taxable.
Not permissible to tear the corporate veil to see whether partners of vendors same as shareholders of vendee.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Karkhanis, learned counsel for the appellant. urges that the Doughtys case 1 was wrongly decided in one respect and that the vendors and the vendee being different entities. it is not permissible to tear the corporate veil

holdings.text: The sale was the sale of the whole concern and no part of the slump price is attributable to the cost of land; no part of the slump price is taxable

anchor.surface_text: In our view the sale was the sale of the whole companycern and numberpart of the slump price is attributable to the companyt of land. If this is so, it is clear from the decision of this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Kerala v. 14lest Coast Chemicals and Industries Ltd. 1  and Doughtys case 2  that numberpart of the slump price is taxable. We, therefore, answer question No. 3 in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied precedents from Doughty's case and West Coast Chemicals & Industries Ltd.; confirmed slump transaction as going concern sale with no separable attribution to stock-in-trade (land) due to lack of evidence of separate valuation

holdings.text: The transaction was a sale of the business as a going concern

anchor.surface_text: As we are inclined to answer the third question in the favour of the vendors, it is number necessary to deal with the other questions and the arguments addressed in respect of them. The Appellate Tribunal held in this case that the sale was a sale of business as a going companycern.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted Appellate Tribunal's finding and confirmed from clause 1 of the agreement; basis for applying slump sale precedents

holdings.text: The values stated in the schedule represent book costs as per vendors' books, not market values or separate sale valuations of land; no evidence of valuation on date of sale

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that in the schedule the price of land is stated does number lead to the companyclusion that part of the slump price is necessarily attributable to the land sold. there is numberevidence that any attempt was made to evaluate the land on the date of sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Schedule reflects book entries without effort to value land at market on sale date, especially as vendee promoted by vendors; adding goodwill figure does not prove market value

holdings.text: Vendors carried on business of buying land, developing it (roads, drains, electricity, school) and then selling, not purely buying and selling

anchor.surface_text: In this case the vendors were engaged in buying land, developing it and then selling it. The agreement itself shows that the vendors had already incurred debts and liabilities for development expenses such as opening out roads, laying out drains and, sanitary arrangements, providing electricity and providing for a school.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished from pure trading business in Doughty's case; development activities make attribution of slump price to land even more difficult

holdings.text: Not necessary to consider lifting corporate veil or identity of partners/shareholders as sale treated on its terms

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Karkhanis, learned companynsel for the appellant. urges that the Doughtys case 1 was wrongly decided in one respect and that the vendors and the vendee being different entities. it is number permissible to tear the companyporate veil to see whether the partners of the vendors were the same persons as the shareholders of the vendee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to address as decision on merits of slump sale does not require piercing veil; obiter rejection of appellant's invitation to distinguish Doughty on this ground

anchor.surface_text: Doughty v. Commissioner of Taxes, 1 he held that as the transfer is a transfer of all assets of the firm to a companypany the transfer is a capital sales.

precedents.cited_holding: sale of whole business as going concern does not give rise to taxable profit on stock-in-trade

anchor.surface_text: relying on the passage already cited above from Doghtys case that the vendors business was a business of purely buying and selling land.
